definitions.definition: to hand something to somebody so that they can look at it, use it or keep it for a time
definitions.sensetop: give something to somebodygive somebody something

examples.text: Give the letter to your mother when you've read it.
She gave her ticket to the woman at the check-in desk.
Give your mother the letter.
They were all given a box to carry.

definitions.definition: to hand something to somebody as a present; to allow somebody to have something as a present
definitions.sensetop: give somebody somethinggive something to somebodygive (something)

examples.text: What are you giving your father for his birthday?
She was given a huge bunch of flowers.
Did you give the waiter a tip?
She gave a couple of pounds to a homeless man.
We all agreed not to give presents this year.
They say it's better to give than to receive.

definitions.definition: to provide somebody with something
definitions.sensetop: give somebody somethinggive something to somebodygive something

examples.text: They were all thirsty so I gave them a drink.
Give me your name and address.
We've been given a 2 per cent pay increase.
I was hoping you would give me a job.
He was given a new heart in a five-hour operation.
**Give me** some **time** to decide.
We should at least **give him the opportunity** to explain why he did this.
This should **give** you some **idea** of the extent of the problem.
Can you **give** us some **sense **of exactly what is at stake here?
We'll give you all the help we can.
She wants a job that gives her more responsibility.
Can I give you a ride to the station?
I'll give you *(= allow you to have)* ten minutes to prepare your answer.
Don't give me any of that backchat *(= don't be rude)*.
He gives Italian lessons to his colleagues.
The reforms should **give a** better **chance** to the less able children.
She **gave** some helpful **advice**.
She **gives the impression** of being very busy.
I was asked to **give evidence** at the trial.
She gave me some medicine that sent me off to sleep.
Let me give you a word of advice.
The dark glasses gave him an air of mystery.
This shampoo will give your hair a nice healthy sheen.
We want to give you the best possible care.
They couldn't give me any more information.
He just left. He wouldn't give a reason.
The police did not give any details of the attack.

definitions.definition: to pay money to a charity, etc., to help people
definitions.sensetop: give to somethinggive somethinggive something to something

examples.text: We need your help—please give generously.
They both gave regularly to charity.
I gave a small donation.
A lot of people give money to good causes.

definitions.definition: to pay in order to have or do something
definitions.sensetop: give somebody somethinggive somebody something for somethinggive somethinggive something for something

examples.text: I'll give you £100 and not a penny more!
How much will you give me for the car?
I'd give anything to see him again.
I gave £50 for the lot.

definitions.definition: used with a noun to describe a particular action, giving the same meaning as the related verb

examples.text: She gave a shrug of her shoulders *(= shrugged*).
He turned to us and gave a big smile *(= smiled broadly)*.
She looked up from her work and gave a yawn *(= yawned)*.
He gave a loud cry *(= cried out loudly)* and fell to the floor.
Her work has given pleasure to *(= pleased)* millions of readers.
He gave her a kiss *(= kissed her)*.
I have to admit that the news gave us a shock *(= shocked us)*.
He **gave me a** suspicious **look** *(= looked at me suspiciously)*.

definitions.definition: to produce a particular feeling in somebody

examples.text: All that driving has given me a headache.
Go for a walk. It'll give you an appetite.

definitions.definition: to make a phone call to somebody

examples.text: Give me a call tomorrow.
I'll give you a ring.

definitions.definition: to judge somebody/something to be of a particular standard
definitions.sensetop: give somebody/something sthgive somethinggive something to somebody/something

examples.text: She had given the assignment an A.
I give it ten out of ten for originality.
He virtually never gives a grade of less than C.
I gave top marks to her essay.

definitions.definition: to pass an illness onto somebody and make them ill
definitions.sensetop: give somebody somethinggive something to somebody

examples.text: You've given me your cold.
She'd given the bug to all her colleagues.

definitions.definition: to make somebody suffer a particular punishment
definitions.sensetop: give somebody somethinggive something to somebody

examples.text: The judge gave him a nine-month suspended sentence.
We discussed what punishment should be given to the boys.

definitions.definition: if you give a party, you organize it and invite people

examples.text: We're giving a party to celebrate our silver wedding.

definitions.definition: to perform something in public

examples.text: He **gave a** rousing **performance** of the Bob Marley song.
She gave a reading from her latest volume of poetry.
The President will be giving a press conference this afternoon.
She **gave a** fine **speech** to the waiting crowd.

definitions.definition: to use time, energy, etc. for somebody/something
definitions.sensetop: give somebody/something sthgive something to somebody/something

examples.text: I gave the matter a lot of thought.
I gave a lot of thought to the matter.
The government has given top priority to reforming the tax system.

definitions.definition: to predict that something will last a particular length of time

examples.text: That marriage won't last. I'll give them two years at the outside.

definitions.definition: to say that a player or the ball is in a particular position or that a goal has been scored

examples.text: The umpire gave the ball out.
The ref gave the goal.

definitions.definition: to bend or stretch under pressure

examples.text: The branch began to give under his weight.
We can't go on like this—**something's got to give**.

definitions.definition: to agree to change your mind or give up some of your demands

examples.text: You're going to have to give a little.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody that you do not accept what they say

examples.text: ‘I didn't have time to do it.’ ‘Oh, don't give me that!’

definitions.definition: to be willing, in a relationship, to accept what somebody else wants and to give up some of what you want

examples.text: You're going to have to learn to give and take.

definitions.definition: to react with equal force when somebody attacks or criticizes you

examples.text: She can give as good as she gets.

definitions.definition: to show your approval of somebody by clapping your hands

examples.text: Give it up for Ed Sheeran!

definitions.definition: used to say that you prefer a particular thing or person to the one that has just been mentioned

examples.text: We don't go out much. Give me a quiet night in front of the TV any day!

definitions.definition: if something is correct give or take a particular amount, it is approximately correct

examples.text: It'll take about three weeks, give or take a day or so.

definitions.definition: to make somebody believe/understand something

examples.text: I was given to understand that she had resigned.

definitions.definition: to severely punish or criticize somebody for doing something wrong

examples.text: My son was rude to my friends so I gave him what for.

definitions.definition: used to ask people to drink a toast to somebody

examples.text: Ladies and gentlemen, I give you Geoff Ogilby!

definitions.definition: used when you are admitting that something is true
what is happening?; what is the news?

wordOrigin: Old English giefan, gefan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch geven and German geben.
